snippet: An admirer of the man known best for killing Alexander Hamilton is showing much of his collection of Burriana at the Groiler Club starting May 16.
abstract: Eve M Kahn Antiques column; lawyer Brian D Hardison's collection of artifacts related to Aaron Burr, Revolutionary War hero best known for killing Alexander Hamilton, will be on view at the Grolier Club in Manhattan; dealers and auction houses are sifting through the inventory of New York tribal-art dealer Joseph G Gerena; B&B Carousell, antique amusement ride that New York City bought for $1.8 million in 2005, is undergoing restoration. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Brian D. Hardison, a lawyer and judge on the outskirts of Atlanta, has built a persuasive case in defense of Aaron Burr. Since the 1990s he has been acquiring mounds of paperwork showing this politician's sympathetic sides. Much of the collection goes on view May 16 to July 28 at the Grolier Club in Manhattan. The exhibition, ''Aaron Burr Returns to New York: An Exhibit of Burr and His Contemporaries,'' spans his career: from his heroism under fire during the Revolutionary War, through his remorse for his killing of Alexander Hamilton, to his stoic reactions to family tragedy and his persistent ability to earn a living.

headline.main: Making a Case to Remember Burr
